Murdaugh Family

The Murdaugh family is a prominent American family from South Carolina, known for their involvement in law, politics, and business. The family has been a part of the state's history for over a century and has produced several notable members, including politicians, lawyers, and judges.

# 14th District

The Murdaugh family's influence in South Carolina is largely centered in the 14th Judicial Circuit, also known as the Lowcountry. This region includes several counties, including Colleton, Beaufort, Jasper, and Hampton. The family has played a significant role in the region's politics and law for generations.

# Family Law Firm

The Murdaugh family's law firm, Peters Murdaugh Parker Eltzroth & Detrick (PMPED), was founded in 1910 by Randolph Murdaugh Sr. The firm has been a major player in the state's legal community for over a century, handling cases ranging from personal injury to medical malpractice. The firm has also been involved in several high-profile cases, including a landmark asbestos case in the 1970s.

# Murdaugh Hunting Estate

The Murdaugh family owns a large hunting estate in Islandton, South Carolina, which has been in the family for generations. The estate, known as Moselle, covers over 1,700 acres and features several homes, barns, and hunting lodges. The estate has been the site of numerous hunting parties and social events over the years.

# Notable Members

## Randolph Murdaugh Sr.

Randolph Murdaugh Sr. was the founder of the Murdaugh family law firm and a prominent lawyer in his own right. He was born in 1887 and graduated from the University of South Carolina Law School in 1910. Murdaugh Sr. served in World War I and later became a judge in the 14th Judicial Circuit.

## Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr.

Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr. was the son of Randolph Murdaugh Sr. and a lawyer in his own right. He was born in 1927 and graduated from the University of South Carolina Law School in 1950. Murdaugh Jr. served in the South Carolina House of Representatives and later became a judge in the 14th Judicial Circuit.

## Randolph Murdaugh III

Randolph Murdaugh III was the son of Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr. and a lawyer in his own right. He was born in 1958 and graduated from the University of South Carolina Law School in 1982. Murdaugh III was a partner in the Murdaugh family law firm and served on the board of the South Carolina Trial Lawyers Association.

## Alex Murdaugh

Alex Murdaugh was the son of Randolph Murdaugh III and a lawyer in his own right. He was born in 1968 and graduated from the University of South Carolina Law School in 1994. Murdaugh was a partner in the Murdaugh family law firm and served on the board of the South Carolina Trial Lawyers Association.

## Maggie Murdaugh

Maggie Murdaugh was the wife of Alex Murdaugh and a socialite in her own right. She was born in 1968 and graduated from the University of South Carolina in 1991. Maggie was a member of the Junior League of Charleston and served on the board of the Gibbes Museum of Art.

## Buster Murdaugh

Buster Murdaugh was the son of Alex Murdaugh and a student at the University of South Carolina at the time of his death. He was born in 1996 and was a junior at the university when he died in 2021.

## Paul Murdaugh

Paul Murdaugh was the son of Alex Murdaugh and a student at the University of South Carolina at the time of his death. He was born in 1999 and was a junior at the university when he died in 2021.

# Alex Murdaugh Murders and Other Legal Issues

Alex Murdaugh has been at the center of several high-profile legal issues in recent years, including the murders of his wife and son.

## Ongoing Investigations and Legal Actions

### Murder of Stephen Smith

Stephen Smith was a 19-year-old man who was found dead on the side of the road in Hampton County, South Carolina, in 2015. The case was initially ruled a hit-and-run, but it was reopened in 2021 after new evidence came to light. Alex Murdaugh's son, Buster, was a suspect in the case, but he was never charged.

### Death of Gloria Satterfield

Gloria Satterfield was the Murdaugh family's housekeeper, who died in 2018 after falling down the stairs at the Murdaugh family home. The case was initially ruled an accident, but it was reopened in 2021 after new evidence came to light. Alex Murdaugh was accused of embezzling money from Satterfield's estate.

### Death of Mallory Beach

Mallory Beach was a 19-year-old woman who died in a boating accident in Beaufort County, South Carolina, in 2019. Alex Murdaugh's son, Paul, was charged with manslaughter in connection with the accident.

### Assisted Suicide Fraud

Alex Murdaugh was accused of hiring a hitman to kill him in a staged robbery, in an attempt to collect a life insurance policy. The hitman, Curtis Smith, was charged with attempted murder.

### Embezzlement

Alex Murdaugh was accused of embezzling money from his law firm and from the estates of several clients.

### Charges for Narcotics Distribution

Alex Murdaugh was charged with narcotics distribution after he was found to have been prescribing opioids to several people.

### Lindsey Edwards Allegations

Lindsey Edwards, a former girlfriend of Alex Murdaugh, accused him of physical and emotional abuse.

### Forge Consulting Lawsuit

Alex Murdaugh was sued by Forge Consulting, a company that claimed he had embezzled money from them.

### Santis-Cristiani Lawsuit

Alex Murdaugh was sued by Santis-Cristiani, a company that claimed he had embezzled money from them.

### Criminal Tax Evasion

Alex Murdaugh was charged with criminal tax evasion after he was found to have failed to pay taxes on several million dollars in income.

## Convictions, Civil Judgments, Settlements, and Sanctions

### Asset Custody

Alex Murdaugh's assets were frozen by the court, pending the outcome of several lawsuits.

### Physical Custody

Alex Murdaugh was placed under house arrest, pending the outcome of several lawsuits.

### Disbarment

Alex Murdaugh was disbarred by the South Carolina Supreme Court, pending the outcome of several lawsuits.

### Murders of Maggie and Paul

Alex Murdaugh was charged with the murders of his wife and son.

### Fraud and Money Laundering Charges

Alex Murdaugh was charged with several counts of fraud and money laundering.

#### State Indictments

Alex Murdaugh was indicted by the state on several counts of fraud and money laundering.

#### Federal Indictment 22 Counts

Alex Murdaugh was indicted by the federal government on 22 counts of fraud and money laundering.

article:
2023 India Open (badminton)

The 2023 India Open, officially known as the Yonex-Sunrise India Open 2023, was a badminton tournament that took place at the K. D. Jadhav Indoor Hall in New Delhi, India, from January 17 to January 22, 2023. The tournament was part of the 2023 BWF World Tour and was classified as a Super 750 event.

# Tournament

## Venue

The 2023 India Open was held at the K. D. Jadhav Indoor Hall in New Delhi, India. The venue has a seating capacity of approximately 2,000 spectators and has hosted several international badminton tournaments in the past.

## Point distribution

The 2023 India Open was a Super 750 event, which means that the tournament offered a significant number of world ranking points to the participants. The point distribution for the tournament was as follows:

* Winner: 11,000 points
* Runner-up: 9,350 points
* Semi-finalists: 7,700 points
* Quarter-finalists: 6,050 points
* Round of 16: 4,320 points
* Round of 32: 3,200 points
* Qualifiers: 2,100 points

## Prize money

The total prize money for the 2023 India Open was $850,000. The prize money was distributed among the participants as follows:

* Men's singles: $60,000 (winner), $30,000 (runner-up), $15,000 (semi-finalists), $7,500 (quarter-finalists)
* Women's singles: $60,000 (winner), $30,000 (runner-up), $15,000 (semi-finalists), $7,500 (quarter-finalists)
* Men's doubles: $60,000 (winners), $30,000 (runners-up), $15,000 (semi-finalists), $7,500 (quarter-finalists)
* Women's doubles: $60,000 (winners), $30,000 (runners-up), $15,000 (semi-finalists), $7,500 (quarter-finalists)
* Mixed doubles: $60,000 (winners), $30,000 (runners-up), $15,000 (semi-finalists), $7,500 (quarter-finalists)

# Men's singles

## Seeds

The top eight seeds in the men's singles event were:

1. Viktor Axelson (Denmark)
2. Lee Zii Jia (Malaysia)
3. Loh Kean Yew (Singapore)
4. Lakshya Sen (India)
5. Jonatan Christie (Indonesia)
6. Ng Ka Long Angus (Hong Kong)
7. Rasmus Gemke (Denmark)
8. Hans-Kristian Solberg Vittinghus (Denmark)

## Finals

The men's singles final was played between Viktor Axelson and Jonatan Christie. Axelson won the match in straight games, 21-14, 21-15.

## Top half

### Section 1

In the top half of the men's singles draw, Viktor Axelson was the top seed. He began his campaign with a comfortable win over Sourabh Verma, 21-12, 21-11. In the next round, he defeated qualifier Priyanshu Rajawat, 21-15, 21-18. Axelson then defeated Rasmus Gemke in the quarter-finals, 21-18, 21-15.

### Section 2

In the second section of the top half, Loh Kean Yew was the third seed. He began his campaign with a win over Sameer Verma, 21-19, 21-18. In the next round, he defeated H.S. Prannoy, 21-17, 21-19. However, Loh Kean Yew lost to Lakshya Sen in the quarter-finals, 21-10, 19-21, 21-18.

## Bottom half

### Section 3

In the bottom half of the men's singles draw, Lee Zii Jia was the second seed. He began his campaign with a win over qualifier Sathish Kumar Karunakaran, 21-15, 21-14. In the next round, he defeated Harsheel Dani, 21-11, 21-13. However, Lee Zii Jia lost to Jonatan Christie in the quarter-finals, 21-14, 21-16.

### Section 4

In the fourth section of the bottom half, Lakshya Sen was the fourth seed. He began his campaign with a win over Sankar Muthusamy, 21-14, 21-18. In the next round, he defeated Parupalli Kashyap, 21-15, 21-18. Lakshya Sen then defeated Loh Kean Yew in the quarter-finals, 21-10, 19-21, 21-18. However, he lost to Viktor Axelson in the semi-finals, 21-19, 21-18.

# Women's singles

## Seeds

The top eight seeds in the women's singles event were:

1. Akane Yamaguchi (Japan)
2. An Se-young (South Korea)
3. Chen Yufei (China)
4. Pusarla V. Sindhu (India)
5. Carolina Marin (Spain)
6. Ratchanok Intanon (Thailand)
7. He Bingjiao (China)
8. Pornpawee Chochuwong (Thailand)

## Finals

The women's singles final was played between Akane Yamaguchi and An Se-young. Akane Yamaguchi won the match in straight games, 22-20, 21-13.

## Top half

### Section 1

In the top half of the women's singles draw, Akane Yamaguchi was the top seed. She began her campaign with a comfortable win over Saina Nehwal, 21-14, 21-18. In the next round, she defeated Aakarshi Kashyap, 21-19, 21-14. Yamaguchi then defeated He Bingjiao in the quarter-finals, 21-17, 21-14.

### Section 2

In the second section of the top half, Chen Yufei was the third seed. She began her campaign with a win over Ira Sharma, 21-17, 21-18. In the next round, she defeated Malvika Bansod, 21-16, 21-17. However, Chen Yufei lost to Pusarla V. Sindhu in the quarter-finals, 21-14, 21-14.

## Bottom half

### Section 3

In the bottom half of the women's singles draw, An Se-young was the second seed. She began her campaign with a win over Jakka Vaishnavi Reddy, 21-15, 21-12. In the next round, she defeated Mugdha Agrey, 21-13, 21-15. An Se-young then defeated Ratchanok Intanon in the quarter-finals, 21-14, 21-19.

### Section 4

In the fourth section of the bottom half, Pusarla V. Sindhu was the fourth seed. She began her campaign with a win over Tanya Hemanth, 21-16, 21-16. In the next round, she defeated Ashmita Chaliha, 21-19, 21-16. Pusarla V. Sindhu then defeated Chen Yufei in the quarter-finals, 21-14, 21-14. However, she lost to Akane Yamaguchi in the semi-finals, 21-19, 21-14.

# Men's doubles

## Seeds

The top eight seeds in the men's doubles event were:

1. Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty (India)
2. Goh V. Shem and Tan Wee Kiong (Malaysia)
3. Fajar Alfian and Muhammad Rian Ardianto (Indonesia)

8. Kim Astrup and Anders Skaarup Rasmussen (Denmark)

## Finals

The men's doubles final was played between Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty and Aaron Chia and Soh Wooi Yik. Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty won the match in straight games, 21-15, 22-20.

## Top half

### Section 1

In the top half of the men's doubles draw, Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty were the top seeds. They began their campaign with a comfortable win over Arjun M.R. and Dhruv Kapila, 21-13, 21-18. In the next round, they defeated Goh V. Shem and Tan Wee Kiong, 21-19, 21-17. In the second section of the top half, Lee Yang and Wang Chi-Lin were the fourth seeds. They began their campaign with a win over Krishna Prasad Garaga and Vishnu Vardhan Goud Panjala, 21-14, 21-16. In the next round, they defeated Ong Yew Sin and Teo Ee Yi, 21-19, 21-18. However, Lee Yang and Wang Chi-Lin lost to Aaron Chia and Soh Wooi Yik in the semi-finals, 21-17, 21-19.

## Bottom half

### Section 3

In the bottom half of the men's doubles draw, Goh V. Shem and Tan Wee Kiong were the second seeds. They began their campaign with a win over Senthil Vel Arjun and Venkatesh Prasad, 21-15, 21-14. In the next round, they defeated Nithin H.V. and Viswanath B. 21-16, 21-14. However, Goh V. Shem and Tan Wee Kiong lost to Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty in the quarter-finals, 21-19, 21-17.

### Section 4

In the fourth section of the bottom half, Aaron Chia and Soh Wooi Yik were the fifth seeds. They began their campaign with a win over S. Sunjith and S. Santhosh, 21-10, 21-15. In the next round, they defeated Kim Astrup and Anders Skaarup Rasmussen, 21-19, 21-16. Aaron Chia and Soh Wooi Yik then defeated Lee Yang and Wang Chi-Lin in the semi-finals, 21-17, 21-19.

# Women's doubles

## Seeds

The top eight seeds in the women's doubles event were:

1. Chen Qingchen and Jia Yifan (China)

The women's doubles final was played between Chen Qingchen and Jia Yifan and Kim So-yeong and Kong Hee-yong. Chen Qingchen and Jia Yifan won the match in straight games, 21-14, 21-16.

## Top half

## Bottom half

### Section 3

In the bottom half of the women's doubles draw, Kim So-yeong and Kong Hee-yong were the third seeds. They began their campaign with a win over Shikha Gautam and Kriti Bharadwaj, 21-15, 21-17. article:
Giorgio Napolitano

Giorgio Napolitano is an Italian politician who served as the 11th President of Italy from 2006 to 2015. He was the first President of Italy to be re-elected for a second term. Napolitano's long and distinguished career in Italian politics spanned over six decades, during which he played a significant role in shaping the country's history.

#Early life

Giorgio Napolitano was born on June 29, 1925, in Naples, Italy. His family was of modest means, and his father was a lawyer. Napolitano's early life was marked by the tumultuous events of World War II, which had a profound impact on his future.

#Early political career

##World War II and anti-fascist resistance

During World War II, Napolitano joined the Italian resistance movement against the fascist regime of Benito Mussolini. He was part of the liberal-socialist group, which later became the Italian Socialist Party. Napolitano's involvement in the resistance movement deepened his commitment to democratic values and social justice.

##From post-war years to the Hungarian Revolution of 1956

After the war, Napolitano became increasingly involved in politics, joining the Italian Socialist Party. He quickly rose through the ranks, becoming a prominent figure in the party. In 1956, he was among the few Italian socialists who opposed the Soviet invasion of Hungary, which further solidified his commitment to democratic principles.

#Leading member of the Italian Communist Party

##From the 1960s to 1980s

In 1963, Napolitano joined the Italian Communist Party (PCI), which was then the largest communist party in Western Europe. He quickly became a leading figure in the party, known for his moderate and reformist views. Napolitano played a crucial role in shaping the PCI's policies, particularly in the areas of foreign policy and social welfare. During the 1970s and 1980s, he was a key figure in the party's efforts to modernize and democratize.

#After the Italian Communist Party

##President of the Chamber of Deputies

In 1992, Napolitano was elected President of the Chamber of Deputies, Italy's lower house of parliament. He held this position until 1994, during which time he played a key role in shaping the country's response to the Tangentopoli scandal, which led to the collapse of the First Republic.

##Late 1990s and early 2000s

In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Napolitano became increasingly involved in European politics. He was a strong supporter of European integration and played a key role in Italy's efforts to join the Eurozone. In 2001, he was appointed Minister of the Interior in the government of Silvio Berlusconi, a position he held until 2006.

#President of Italy

##First term (2006–2013)

###Election

In 2006, Napolitano was elected President of Italy, succeeding Carlo Azeglio Ciampi. He was elected on the fourth round of voting, with the support of the centre-left coalition.

###Prodi Cabinet

Napolitano played a key role in appointing Romano Prodi as Prime Minister in 2006. He worked closely with Prodi to shape the country's economic and social policies. However, the Prodi government was short-lived, and Napolitano was faced with a series of political crises.

###2008 political crisis

In 2008, the Prodi government collapsed, and Napolitano was forced to appoint a new Prime Minister. He chose Silvio Berlusconi, who formed a centre-right government.

###Eluana Englaro incident

In 2009, Napolitano was involved in a high-profile controversy surrounding the case of Eluana Englaro, a woman who had been in a coma for 17 years. Napolitano refused to sign a decree that would have allowed Englaro's father to remove her life support, sparking a national debate about euthanasia.

###2011 political crisis

In 2011, the Berlusconi government collapsed, and Napolitano was faced with another political crisis. He appointed Mario Monti as Prime Minister, who formed a technocratic government.

##Second term (2013–2015)

###Re-election

In 2013, Napolitano was re-elected President of Italy, becoming the first President to serve a second term. He was re-elected on the sixth round of voting, with the support of the centre-left coalition.

###Letta Cabinet

Napolitano played a key role in appointing Enrico Letta as Prime Minister in 2013. He worked closely with Letta to shape the country's economic and social policies.

###Renzi Cabinet

In 2014, Letta resigned, and Napolitano appointed Matteo Renzi as Prime Minister. Renzi formed a centre-left government and implemented a series of reforms.

##Resignation

Napolitano resigned as President of Italy on January 14, 2015, citing his advanced age and declining health.

##Later life

After his resignation, Napolitano retired from politics and dedicated himself to writing and public speaking. He has written several books on politics and history and has been a vocal critic of populist and nationalist movements.

#Personal life

##Relations with the Catholic Church

Napolitano has always maintained a complex relationship with the Catholic Church. While he is a self-described atheist, he has always respected the Church's role in Italian society. He has been a strong supporter of the Church's social teachings and has worked closely with Catholic organizations on issues such as poverty and migration.

##Death and state funeral

Giorgio Napolitano passed away on January 31, 2023, at the age of 97. He was given a state funeral, which was attended by dignitaries from across Italy and Europe.

#Legacy

Giorgio Napolitano's legacy is complex and multifaceted. He is remembered as a champion of democracy and social justice, who played a key role in shaping Italy's post-war history. He is also remembered as a strong supporter of European integration and a vocal critic of populist and nationalist movements.

#Electoral history

##First-past-the-post elections

* 1953 Italian general election: elected to the Chamber of Deputies for the Italian Socialist Party
* 1958 Italian general election: re-elected to the Chamber of Deputies for the Italian Socialist Party
* 1963 Italian general election: re-elected to the Chamber of Deputies for the Italian Socialist Party
* 1968 Italian general election: re-elected to the Chamber of Deputies for the Italian Communist Party
* 1972 Italian general election: re-elected to the Chamber of Deputies for the Italian Communist Party
* 1976 Italian general election: re-elected to the Chamber of Deputies for the Italian Communist Party
* 1979 Italian general election: re-elected to the Chamber of Deputies for the Italian Communist Party

##Presidential elections

* 2006 Italian presidential election: elected President of Italy on the fourth round of voting
* 2013 Italian presidential election: re-elected President of Italy on the sixth round of voting

#Honours

##National honours

* Knight Grand Cross of the Order of Merit of the Italian Republic (2006)
* Collar of the Order of Merit of the Italian Republic (2015)

##Foreign honours

* Grand Cross of the Order of Saint Michael and Saint George (United Kingdom, 2009)
* Grand Cross of the Order of the White Eagle (Poland, 2012)
* Grand Cross of the Order of the Legion of Honour (France, 2012)

The year 2022 in Philippine television was marked by significant events, debuts, and milestones in the industry. Indonesia at the 2023 ASEAN Para Games

The 2023 ASEAN Para Games, officially known as the 12th ASEAN Para Games, is a multi-sport event that took place in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, from June 3 to June 9, 2023. Indonesia sent a delegation of athletes to compete in various sports, including badminton, boccia, goalball, powerlifting, sitting volleyball, and wheelchair basketball.

#Medal Summary

##Medal by sport

Indonesia won a total of 146 medals across six sports, with the majority coming from badminton and powerlifting.

| Sport | Gold | Silver | Bronze | Total |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Badminton | 10 | 8 | 4 | 22 |
| Boccia | 2 | 1 | 2 | 5 |
| Goalball | 0 | 1 | 0 | 1 |
| Powerlifting | 14 | 6 | 4 | 24 |
| Sitting volleyball | 2 | 0 | 0 | 2 |
| Wheelchair basketball | 0 | 2 | 1 | 3 |
| Total | 28 | 18 | 11 | 57 |
